channel.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
channel.description:
1) Deob 2) Extension bot 3) BCEL 4) Reflection 5) Java-agent 6) Process attaching
These are the ones that came into my mind right now. I got interested in RS2 botmaking, but it would be nice if someone would give me some hints on what botmaking ways are detected and what are considered safe. What does Jagex check for? Do they check for packages and classes in them? What kind of class file modifications are detected and do they check for field/method access specifiers?
Are any of these botmaking ways 100% undetectable? Or do you have to exactly know what kind of detection methods Jagex uses so that you can modify those methods to not detect what they're meant to detect?
Thanks.

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:23, topic:314256”][quote author=zstars link=topic=410719.msg3035704#msg3035704 date=1258740536]
Seeing how the JVM is just a normal process, you could read its raw memory, which in practise wouldn’t be detectable.
[/quote]but the memory is not statically defined (since its ran in a virtual environment), and because of this, the memory address for everything will be different for every jvm ran

so unless you look for specific patterns in memory to find certain data, reading raw memory alone will not suffice[/quote]

unless your data is utf-8, then subtracting 97 will work

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

so unless you look for specific patterns in memory to find certain data, reading raw memory alone will not suffice

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

If something is on a computer, it is possible to do anything you want, with that information, on that computer… Given the time and the resources… The entire point of the “detection” is to be a deterrence. If it’s too much work to cheat, then it’s obvious no one will & vice versa.

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:16, topic:314256”][quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=410719.msg3035721#msg3035721 date=1258743987]

Seeing how the JVM is just a normal process, you could read its raw memory, which in practise wouldn’t be detectable.
[/quote]until you use this data to help you to move your mouse and click a specific point… (im just being controversial, they most likely dont check movements/clicks that much in depth)

unless you build a robot to move your mouse, the one on your desk.[/quote]That would make no difference, the principle would still stand since you would have to program the bots movement algorithms.

[quote=“zstars, post:17, topic:314256”]Even if they analyzed input to detect bots, memory reading would still be undetectable. They are different components. On either case, simulating realistic mouse input isn’t particularly hard either. Simply calculating the best path to the target position and following it loosely using a normal distribution RNG would yield good results. If they statistically analyzed enough data they might still find bot suspects automatically, but it’s probably not reasonable to expect them to and the mouse moving algorithm could be optimized using the same means anyway.[/quote]Yeah I mean ofcourse, I was just trying to be controversial.

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Even if they analyzed input to detect bots, memory reading would still be undetectable. They are different components. On either case, simulating realistic mouse input isn’t particularly hard either. Simply calculating the best path to the target position and following it loosely using a normal distribution RNG would yield good results. If they statistically analyzed enough data they might still find bot suspects automatically, but it’s probably not reasonable to expect them to and the mouse moving algorithm could be optimized using the same means anyway.

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @933pm 933pm
item.description:
@933pm wrote:

Unhandled:

You should also bear in mind the possibility of them using native code to do various checks, now that they have that option quite readily available.

I’m an idiot for not remembering but I’m going to guess you’re talking about the jagmisc class?

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Tenen, post:9, topic:314256”][quote author=Synt[a]x link=topic=410719.msg3029765#msg3029765 date=1258291179]
Everything is detectable, the question is what ones do they they actually check for.
The thing is it doesnt matter which method you use here, if you want an efficient bot you will still have to get data from the client, either by reflecting or injecting.
BCEL and Reflection are not bot making methods, they are merely methods of getting data from the client, and intruding the client is ALWAYS detectable. The only thing that wouldn’t be detectable is using color and character recognition or somehow predicting the game and and acting based on your predictions, this has never been done before and I doubt it ever will be.
[/quote]
how the hell is Reflection detectable? and, not everything is detectable.[/quote]in order for reflection to work, you badskis need to be in the same classloader, because you arent using any bytecode editing, they will be potentially able to reflect your classes

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“Synt[a”]x link=topic=410719.msg3029765#msg3029765 date=1258291179]
Everything is detectable, the question is what ones do they they actually check for.
The thing is it doesnt matter which method you use here, if you want an efficient bot you will still have to get data from the client, either by reflecting or injecting.
BCEL and Reflection are not bot making methods, they are merely methods of getting data from the client, and intruding the client is ALWAYS detectable. The only thing that wouldn’t be detectable is using color and character recognition or somehow predicting the game and and acting based on your predictions, this has never been done before and I doubt it ever will be.[/quote]
how the hell is Reflection detectable? and, not everything is detectable.

Read full topic

item.title: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?
item.dc:creator: @Synt_a_x Synt[a]x
item.description:
@Synt_a_x wrote:

Everything is detectable, the question is what ones do they they actually check for.
The thing is it doesnt matter which method you use here, if you want an efficient bot you will still have to get data from the client, either by reflecting or injecting.
BCEL and Reflection are not bot making methods, they are merely methods of getting data from the client, and intruding the client is ALWAYS detectable. The only thing that wouldn’t be detectable is using color and character recognition or somehow predicting the game and and acting based on your predictions, this has never been done before and I doubt it ever will be.

Read full topic
item.source: Which botmaking ways are considered detected and which are not?

These are the ones that came into my mind right now. I got interested in RS2 botmaking, but it would be nice if someone would give me some hints on what botmaking ways are detected and what are considered safe. What does Jagex check for? Do they check for packages and classes in them? What kind of class file modifications are detected and do they check for field/method access specifiers?

Are any of these botmaking ways 100% undetectable? Or do you have to exactly know what kind of detection methods Jagex uses so that you can modify those methods to not detect what they’re meant to detect?

Thanks.
